intro: Carex dioica var. gynocrates, commonly known as the male and female flowering sedge, is a variant of the common sedge that exhibits distinct sexual dimorphism. This plant is a perennial herbaceous species belonging to the Cyperaceae family, characterized by its grass-like foliage and rhizomatous growth habit. It produces separate male and female flowers on different inflorescences, a trait known as dioecy, which is rare among sedges. The male flowers typically appear in terminal spikes, while the female flowers are found in lower, more clustered structures. This botanical feature makes it an interesting subject for studies on plant reproduction and sexual specialization.
